<body style="  bgcolor="white" lang="EN-US" link="blue" vlink="blue">

<div class="Section1">

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><b style=" ><span style="font-size: 28pt; font-family: Arial;">Problem 
F</span></b><span style="font-family: Arial;"><br>
</span><span style="font-size: 20pt"><b><span style="font-family: Arial">Next 
Same-Factored</span></b></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center"><span style="font-family: Arial;"><b style=" >Time Limit: </b>
<span style=" >6</span> Seconds<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style="text-align: justify;">
Just print out the next integer number which has the same prime factors as the given
    number and is less than <strong>2,000,000</strong>.
</p>

<h1 style=" ><span class="StyleArial16pt"><span style="font-family: Arial;">Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></h1>

<p style="text-align: justify;">There will be several test cases (at most <b>
100,000</b>). Each case is a single positive integer <b>n </b>that is less than 
<b>1,000,000</b>, 
on a separate line.</p>

<h1 style=" ><span class="StyleArial16pt"><span style="font-family: Arial;">Output<o:p></o:p></span></span></h1>

<p style="text-align: justify;">For each test case, output a line containing a 
single integer which is the <b>next</b> integer number that have the same prime factors as <b>
    n.</b> In the case that there is no such number print one line stating &quot;<b>Not Exist!</b>&quot;.</p>

<h1><span style="font-family: Arial; color: black;">Sample Input<span style=" >&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span>Output for Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<table style="border: medium none ; background: rgb(204, 204, 204) none repeat scroll 0%; width: 6.7in; -moz-background-clip: initial; -moz-background-origin: initial; -moz-background-inline-policy: initial; border-collapse: collapse;" bgcolor="#cccccc" border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="643">
 <tbody><tr style=" >
  <td style="border: 0.5pt solid windowtext; padding: 0in 5.4pt; width: 239.4pt;" valign="top" width="319"><pre><span style="font-size: 11pt"><b>2</b></span></pre>
	<pre><span style="font-size: 11pt"><b>143</b></span></pre><pre>
<!--[if !supportEmptyParas]--><span style="font-size: 11pt"><b>991</b></span></pre></td>
  <td style="border-style: solid solid solid none; border-color: windowtext windowtext windowtext -moz-use-text-color; border-width: 0.5pt 0.5pt 0.5pt medium; padding: 0in 5.4pt; width: 243pt;" valign="top" width="324">
	<pre><span style="font-size: 11pt"><b>4</b></span></pre>
	<pre><span style="font-size: 11pt"><b>1573</b></span></pre>
	<pre><span style="font-size: 11pt"><b>982081</b></span></pre>
  </td>
 </tr>
</tbody></table>


<div class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;" align="center">

<hr align="center" size="2" width="100%">

</div>

<font face="Arial, Times New Roman">
<b>Problem setter: Hossein Azizpour<br>
</b></font><b><font face="Arial, Times New Roman">Special Thanks to: Ali 
Sharifrazavian<br>
Alternate Solution: Ali Sharifrazavian, Hadi Moshayedi</font></b></div>

UT Annual Programming Contest&nbsp; Qualification Round</font></b></p>

11100||||||false||||||
<img align=right width=300 height=200 src=p11100.jpg><h2>Problem A:  The Trip, 2007</h2>
A number of students are members of a club that travels annually to exotic locations. Their destinations in the past have included Indianapolis, Phoenix, Nashville, Philadelphia, San Jose, 
Atlanta, Eindhoven, Orlando, Vancouver, Honolulu, Beverly Hills, Prague, Shanghai,
and San Antonio.  This spring they are hoping to make a similar trip but aren't
quite sure where or when.
<p>
An issue with the trip is that their very generous sponsors always give them various
knapsacks and other carrying bags that they must pack for their trip home.  As the airline
allows only so many pieces of luggage, they decide to pool their gifts and to pack
one bag within another so as to minimize the total number of pieces they must carry.
<p>
The bags are all exactly the same shape and differ only in their linear dimension
which is a positive integer not exceeding 1000000.  A bag with smaller dimension
will fit in one with larger dimension.  You are to compute which bags to pack within
which others so as to minimize the overall number of pieces of luggage
(i.e. the number of outermost bags).  While maintaining the minimal number of
pieces you are also to minimize the total number of bags in any one piece that
must be carried.
<p>
Standard input contains several test cases.  Each test case consists of an integer
<i>1 &le; n &le; 10000</i> giving the number of bags followed by <i>n</i> integers
on one or more lines,
each giving the dimension of a piece.  A line containing 0 follows the last test
case.  For each test case your output should consist of <i>k</i>, the minimum
number of pieces, followed by <i>k</i> lines, each giving the dimensions of the
bags comprising one piece, separated by spaces.  Each dimension in the
input should appear exactly once in the output, and the bags in each piece must
fit nested one within another.  If there is more than one solution, any will do.  Output
an empty line between cases.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
6
1 1 2 2 2 3
0
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
3
1 2
1 2
3 2
</pre>
<hr><i>Troy Vasiga, Graeme Kemkes, Ian Munro, Gordon V. Cormack</i>

______________________________________________________
11101||||||false||||||
<img src=p11101.gif align=right width=400 height=300>
<h2>Problem B:  Mall Mania</h2>
Waterloo has two giant shopping malls, each enclosing several city blocks.
Kim and Pat like to shop and to walk within the malls but they don't
like walking between the malls because such walking does not contribute
directly to the task at hand:  shopping.  They would therefore like to
know the minimum crossing distance between the malls.
<p>
Each city block is a unit square delimited by streets and avenues.  Streets
run east-west and avenues run north-south.  Both are identified by 
consecutive integers between 0 and 2000.  (Lower numbered avenues
are west of higher numbered avenues and lower numbered streets are south
of higher numbered streets.)  Streets and avenues are narrow so their
thickness may be assumed to be 0.
<p>
Each mall is a contiguous set of complete city blocks.  By contiguous we mean
that any two blocks are connected by some sequence of blocks such that 
consecutive pairs of blocks in the sequence share a side.  The malls do not
intersect and do not surround any empty blocks; that is, the blocks not in
any mall are themselves contiguous.
<p>
Standard input contains several test cases.  Each test case contains the
description of the two malls.  Each mall's description consists of an integer
<i>p&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;4</i>, the perimeter of the mall, followed by one
or more lines containing <i>p</i>
pairs <i>(a,s)</i> giving the coordinates of the avenue-street intersections
contained in the perimeter, in clockwise order.  A line 
containing 0 follows the last test case.
<p>
For each case, output a single integer <i>d</i> -- the minimum walking
distance between the malls, assuming that Kim and Pat always 
walk along streets and avenues.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
4
0 0 0 1 1 1 1 0
6
4 3 4 2 3 2
2 2 2 3
3 3
0
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
2
</pre>
<hr><i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>


______________________________________________________
11102||||||false||||||
<img align=right width=400 height=300 src=p11102a.jpg>
<h2>Problem C:  Moonshine</h2>
Granny is preparing moonshine whiskey for an upcoming family reunion.  Because
her family is large, she needs to make several batches of whiskey, which she collects
in a large metal cream can.  After making, and sampling, several batches Granny 
stumbles and knocks the can on its side.  Fortunately, the lid is tightly fixed
so no whiskey is lost.
<p>
Our question to you is this:  assuming that the depth of whiskey in the can was
<i>k</i> cm with the can sitting upright, what is its depth with the can lying
horizontal?  The can itself is made of two cylinders:  the body with height
<i>h<sub>b</sub></i> and diameter <i>d<sub>b</sub></i>, and the neck with 
height <i>h<sub>n</sub></i> and diameter <i>d<sub>n</sub></i>.  The neck and
body are joined by a tapered conic shoulder such that the overall height of
the can is <i>h</i>.  The bottom and lid of the can are disks of diameter
<i>d<sub>b</sub></i> and <i>d<sub>n</sub></i> respectively.
<p>
Input consists of several test cases.  Each test case consists of a line containing
real numbers <i>k h<sub>b</sub> d<sub>b</sub> h<sub>n</sub> d<sub>n</sub></i> and <i>h.</i>  You may assume that <i>100&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;h&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;h<sub>b</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;h<sub>n</sub></i> and
that <i>100&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;d<sub>b</sub>&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;d<sub>n</sub></i>.   A line containing 0 0 0 0 0 0 follows the last test case.
<p>
For each test case, output a line containing <i>s</i> the depth with the can lying
horizontally, rounded to two decimal places.
<center><img src=p11102b.jpg></center>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
5.625 10.0 10.0 5.0 5.0 15.0
0 0 0 0 0 0
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
5.00
</pre>
<hr><i>Troy Vasiga and Gordon V. Cormack</i>


______________________________________________________
11103||||||false||||||
<img align=right src=p11103.jpg><h2>Problem D:  WFF 'N PROOF</h2>
WFF 'N PROOF is a logic game played with dice.  Each die has six faces representing
some subset of the possible symbols K, A, N, C, E, p, q, r, s, t.
A Well-formed formula (WFF) is any string of these symbols obeying the following
rules:
<ul>
<li>p, q, r, s, and t are WFFs
<li>if <i>w</i> is a WFF, N<i>w</i> is a WFF
<li>if <i>w</i> and <i>x</i> are WFFs, K<i>wx</i>, A<i>wx</i>, C<i>wx</i>,
and E<i>wx</i> are WFFs.
</ul>
The meaning of a WFF is defined as follows:
<ul>
<li>p, q, r, s, and t are logical variables that may take on the value 0 (false) or 
1 (true).
<li>K, A, N, C, E mean <i>and, or, not, implies,</i> and <i>equals</i> as defined
in the truth table below.
</ul>
<center>
<table BORDER COLS=1 WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#CCFFFF" >
<tr>
<td>
<center><b><font color="#000099"><font size=+1>Definitions of K, A, N,
C, and E</font></font></b></center>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<table BORDER COLS=6 WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#CCFFFF" >
<tr>
<td>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1><i>w</i>&nbsp;
<i>x</i></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; K<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; A<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; N<i>w</i></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; C<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; E<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
<p>
Given a collection of symbols resulting from throwing a set of dice, determine the
longest WFF that can be formed from those symbols.
<p>
Input consists of several test cases.  Each test case is a single line containing a
string containing between 1 and 100 of the characters.  A line containing 0 follows the
last case.  For each test case, output a line containing
the longest WFF that can be formed using
some subset of the letters in the string.  If there are several such WFFs, any one
will do.  If no WFF can be constructed,
output a line containing "no WFF possible" as shown below.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
qKpNq
KKN
0
</pre>
<h3>Possible Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
KqNq
no WFF possible
</pre>
<hr><i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>


______________________________________________________
11104||||||false||||||
<img width=400 height=300 align=right src=p11104.jpg><h2>Problem E:  Cousins</h2>
Two strings <i>a</i> and <i>b</i> are defined to be <i>first cousins</i> if
they can be made equal by removing no more than half the characters from each.
For example "abcdef" and "axcyd" are first cousins because we can remove 3
of the 6 characters (b,e,f) from the first string and 2 of the 5 characters
in the second string (x,y) resulting in "acd".  Two strings <i>c</i> and <i>d</i>
are said to be n+1<i>st cousins</i> if there exists a string <i>e</i> that
is a first cousin of <i>c</i> and is an n<i>th</i> cousin of <i>d</i>.
<p>
Given two strings <i>x</i> and <i>y</i>, determine the smallest <i>n&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;1</i> such
that <i>x</i> is an n<i>th</i> cousin of <i>y</i>.
<p>
Input consists of several test cases.  Each test case consists of two lines
representing <i>x</i> and <i>y</i>.  <i>x</i> and <i>y</i> 
each consist of at least 1 and at most 100 lower case letters.  
Two lines containing 0 follow the last test case.
For each test case, output a line containing <i>n</i> or 
<b>not related</b> if <i>x</i> and <i>y</i> are not n<i>th</i> cousins for any <i>n</i>.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
a
b
abb
baa
abcdef
axcyd
0
0
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
2
2
1
</pre>
<hr><i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>


______________________________________________________
11105||||||false||||||
<title>Problem A: Semi-prime <b>H</b>-numbers</title>

<h2>Problem A: Semi-prime <b>H</b>-numbers</h2>

<img src=p11105.jpg align=right hspace=20 vspace =20>

This problem is based on an exercise of David Hilbert, who pedagogically
suggested that one study the theory of <em>4n+1</em> numbers.
Here, we do only a bit of that.
<p>
An <b>H</b>-number is a positive number which is one more than a multiple of four:
1, 5, 9, 13, 17, 21,... are the <b>H</b>-numbers.
For this problem we pretend that these are the <em>only</em> numbers.
The <b>H</b>-numbers are closed under multiplication.
<p>
As with regular integers, we partition the <b>H</b>-numbers into units,
<b>H</b>-primes, and <b>H</b>-composites.
1 is the only unit.
An <b>H</b>-number <b>h</b> is <b>H</b>-prime if it is not the unit, 
and is the product of two <b>H</b>-numbers in only one way: 1 &times; <b>h</b>.
The rest of the numbers are <b>H</b>-composite.
<p>
For examples, the first few <b>H</b>-composites are: 5 &times; 5 = 25,
5 &times; 9 = 45, 5 &times; 13 = 65, 9 &times; 9 = 81, 5 &times; 17 = 85.
<p>
Your task is to count the number of <b>H</b>-semi-primes.
An <b>H</b>-semi-prime is an <b>H</b>-number which is the product of exactly two
<b>H</b>-primes. The two <b>H</b>-primes may be equal or different.
In the example above, all five numbers are <b>H</b>-semi-primes.
125 = 5 &times; 5 &times; 5 is not an <b>H</b>-semi-prime, because it's the
product of three <b>H</b>-primes. 
<p>
Each line of input contains an <b>H</b>-number &le; 1,000,001.
The last line of input contains 0 and this line should not be processed.
<p>
For each inputted <b>H</b>-number <b>h</b>, print a line stating <b>h</b>
and the number of <b>H</b>-semi-primes between 1 and <b>h</b> inclusive, separated by
one space in the format shown in the sample.

<h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>
21 
85
789
0
</pre>


<h3>Output for sample input</h3>
<pre>
21 0
85 5
789 62
</pre>

<hr>

<em>Don Reble</em>


______________________________________________________
11106||||||false||||||
<title>Problem B: Rectilinear polygon</title>

<h2>Problem B: Rectilinear polygon</h2>


<img src=p11106.jpg vspace=20 hspace=20 align=right>

Given is <it>n</it> points with integer coordinates in the plane.  Is
it is possible to construct a simple, that is non-intersecting,
rectilinear polygon with the given points as vertices?  In a
rectilinear polygon there are at least 4 vertices and every edge is
either horizontal or vertical; 
each vertex is an endpoint of exactly one horizontal edge
and one vertical edge.  There are no holes in a polygon.

<p>
The first line of input is an integer giving the number of cases that
follow.  The input of each case starts with an integer 4 &le;
<it>n</it> &le; 100000 giving the number of points for this test case.
It is followed by <it>n</it> pairs of integers specifying the
<it>x</it> and <it>y</it> coordinates of the points for this case.

<p>
The output should contain one line for each case on input.  Each line
should contain one integer number giving the length of the rectilinear 
polygon passing throught the given points when it exists; otherwise,
it should contain <tt>-1</tt>.


<h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>
1
8
1 2
1 0
2 1
2 2
3 2
3 1
4 0
4 2
</pre>


<h3>Output for sample input</h3>
<pre>
12
</pre>

<hr>

<em>Piotr Rudnicki</em>

______________________________________________________
11107||||||false||||||
<img src=p11107.jpg align=right><h2>Problem C: Life Forms</h2>
You may have wondered why most extraterrestrial life forms resemble humans,
differing by superficial traits such as height, colour, wrinkles,
ears, eyebrows and the like.  A few bear no human resemblance; these typically
have geometric or amorphous shapes like cubes, oil slicks
or clouds of dust.
<p>
The answer is given in the 146th episode of <i>Star Trek - The Next Generation</i>,
titled <i>The Chase</i>.  It
turns out that in the vast majority of
the quadrant's life forms ended up with a large fragment of common DNA.
<p>
Given the DNA sequences of several life forms represented as strings
of letters, you are to find the longest
substring that is shared by more than half of them.
<p>Standard input contains several test cases.  Each test case begins with
1 &le; n &le; 100, the number of life forms.  <i>n</i> lines follow; each
contains a string of lower case letters representing the DNA sequence of
a life form.  Each DNA sequence contains at least one and not more than 1000
letters.  A line containing 0 follows the last test case.
<p>
For each test case, output the longest string or strings
shared by more than half of the life forms.  If there are many, output all of
them in alphabetical order.  If there is no solution with at least one
letter, output "?".  Leave an empty line between test cases.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
3
abcdefg
bcdefgh
cdefghi
3
xxx
yyy
zzz
0
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
bcdefg
cdefgh

?
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>

______________________________________________________
11108||||||false||||||
<img align=right src=p11108.jpg><h2>Problem D:  Tautology</h2>
WFF 'N PROOF is a logic game played with dice.  Each die has six faces representing
some subset of the possible symbols K, A, N, C, E, p, q, r, s, t.
A Well-formed formula (WFF) is any string of these symbols obeying the following
rules:
<ul>
<li>p, q, r, s, and t are WFFs
<li>if <i>w</i> is a WFF, N<i>w</i> is a WFF
<li>if <i>w</i> and <i>x</i> are WFFs, K<i>wx</i>, A<i>wx</i>, C<i>wx</i>,
and E<i>wx</i> are WFFs.
</ul>
The meaning of a WFF is defined as follows:
<ul>
<li>p, q, r, s, and t are logical variables that may take on the value 0 (false) or 
1 (true).
<li>K, A, N, C, E mean <i>and, or, not, implies,</i> and <i>equals</i> as defined
in the truth table below.
</ul>
<center>
<table BORDER COLS=1 WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#CCFFFF" >
<tr>
<td>
<center><b><font color="#000099"><font size=+1>Definitions of K, A, N,
C, and E</font></font></b></center>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<table BORDER COLS=6 WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#CCFFFF" >
<tr>
<td>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1><i>w</i>&nbsp;
<i>x</i></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; K<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; A<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; N<i>w</i></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; C<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; E<i>wx</wx></font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 0</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp;&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>

<td><b><font face="Courier New,Courier"><font size=+1>&nbsp; 1</font></font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
<p>
A <i>tautology</i> is a WFF that has value 1 (true) regardless of the values of
its variables.  For example, <i>ApNp</i> is a tautology because it is true regardless
of the value of <i>p</i>.  On the other hand, <i>ApNq</i> is not, because it has the value 0 for
<i>p=0, q=1</i>.
<p>
You must determine whether or not a WFF is a tautology.
<p>
Input consists of several test cases.  Each test case is a single line containing a
WFF with no more than 100 symbols.  A line containing 0 follows the
last case.  For each test case, output a line containing
<i>tautology</i> or <i>not</i> as appropriate.
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
ApNp
ApNq
0
</pre>
<h3>Possible Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
tautology
not
</pre>
<hr><i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>

______________________________________________________
11109||||||false||||||
<img align=right width=400 height=300 src=p11109.jpg>
<h2>Problem E:  Rinse</h2>
Granny's reunion was a smashing success.  Next she is expecting
a visit from Eliot Ness and in anticipation of his visit would like
to remove as much whiskey from the cream can as possible prior
to his visit.
<p>
Granny can upend the cream can, thus pouring its contents on
the ground.  But due to surface tension and the shape of
the can a small amount of the content remains, even after
the can is upended.  Granny has a barrel full of rain water
that she can use to rinse the can several times.  Each
rinse involves pouring some amount of water (perhaps none) into the
cream can, mixing it thoroughly with the existing contents,
and pouring it out.  After each rinse an amount
of liquid remains, some fraction of which is whiskey
and the rest water.
<p>
Mr. Ness' visit is imminent, affording Granny the time to
do at most <i>k</i> rinses.  You are to determine a
rinsing strategy that Granny should employ to minimize
the amount of residual whiskey in the cream can after the 
last rinse.
<p>
Standard input consists of several test cases.  Each test case
is represented by a line with five numbers:
<ul>
<li>0 &lt; k &le; 100 -- an integer denoting the maximum number of rinses
<li>V<sub>b</sub> &gt; 0 -- a real number denoting the volume of available rain water in the barrel
<li>V<sub>w</sub> &gt; 0 -- a real number denoting the volume of whiskey in the cream can
<li>V<sub>r</sub> &gt; 0 -- a real number denoting the volume of liquid that cannot be poured out by upending the can (further liquid might be eliminated by evaporation, but there is insufficient time before Ness' visit for any evaporation to take place)
<li>V<sub>c</sub> &gt; V<sub>w</sub>,V<sub>r</sub> -- a real number denoting the maximum capacity of the cream can.
</ul>
A line containing 0 follows the last case.
For each test case, output <i>r</i>, the number of rinses that Granny
should perform.  On the same line, output <i>r</i> real numbers,
rounded to two decimal places, giving the amount of rain water to
be used for each rinse, in order.
<p>
Note that the total amount of water used in all rinses must not
exceed V<sub>b</sub>.  The total amount of liquid in the cream
can cannot exceed V<sub>c</sub> at any time.  Assume that whiskey
and water mix perfectly and that their volumes are additive; that is,
<i>x</i> units of whiskey and <i>y</i> units of water combine to
form <i>x+y</i> units of liquid.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
2 15.0 25.0 1.0 50.0
0 
</pre>
<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
2 0.00 15.00
</pre>
<hr><i>Gordon V. Cormack</i>


______________________________________________________

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem A - Equidivisions</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem A - Equidivisions">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem A - Equidivisions</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
An equidivision of an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> <TT>x</TT> <I>n</I></SPAN> square array of cells is a partition
of the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUP>2</SUP></SPAN> cells in the array in exactly <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> sets, each one
with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> contiguous cells. Two cells are contiguous when they have
a common side. 

<P>
A good equidivision is composed of contiguous regions. The figures
show a good and a wrong equidivision for a 5<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><TT>x</TT></SPAN>5 square:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{table1.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="150" HEIGHT="150" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11110a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{table1.eps}">

&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{table2.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="150" HEIGHT="150" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11110a.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{table2.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Note that in the second example the cells labeled with <TT>4</TT> describe
three non-contiguous regions and cells labeled with <TT>5</TT> describe two
non-contiguous regions. You must write a program that evaluates if
an equidivision of the cells in a square array is good or not.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
It is understood that a cell in an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> <TT>x</TT> <I>n</I></SPAN> square array is denoted
by a pair <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>)</SPAN>, with <!-- MATH
 $1\le i,j\le n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11110a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I>, <I>j</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11110a.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>n</I></SPAN>. The input file contains
several test cases. Each test case begins with a line indicating <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>,
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>n</I> &lt; 100</SPAN>, the side of the square array to be partitioned. Next,
there are <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> - 1</SPAN> lines, each one corresponding to one partition of
the cells of the square, with some non-negative integer numbers. Consecutive integers
in a line are separated with a single blank character. A line of the
form<P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
a_{1}\, a_{2}\, a_{3}\, a_{4}\,...
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>&nbsp;<I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>&nbsp;<I>a</I><SUB>3</SUB>&nbsp;<I>a</I><SUB>4</SUB>&nbsp;...
</DIV><P></P>
means that cells denoted with the pairs <!-- MATH
 $(a_{1},a_{2})$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>)</SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $(a_{3},a_{4})$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>a</I><SUB>3</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>4</SUB>)</SPAN>,
... belong to one of the areas in the partition. The last area in
the partition is defined by those cells not mentioned in the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> - 1</SPAN>
given lines. If a case begins with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> = 0</SPAN> it means that there are
no more cases to analyze.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each test case <TT>good</TT> must be printed if the equidivision
is good, in other case, <TT>wrong</TT> must be printed. The answers
for the different cases must preserve the order of the input.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
2
1 2 2 1
5
1 1 1 2 1 3 3 2 2 2
2 1 4 2 4 1 5 1 3 1
4 5 5 2 5 3 5 5 5 4
2 5 3 4 3 5 4 3 4 4
5
1 1 1 2 1 3 3 2 2 2
2 1 3 1 4 1 5 1 4 2
4 5 5 2 5 3 5 5 5 4
2 4 1 4 3 5 4 3 4 4
0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
<PRE>
wrong
good
wrong
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11111||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds

  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem B - Generalized Matrioshkas</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem B - Generalized Matrioshkas">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem B - Generalized Matrioshkas</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Vladimir worked for years making <I>matrioshkas</I>, those nesting dolls that certainly represent truly Russian craft. A matrioshka is a doll that may be opened in two halves, so that one finds another doll inside. Then this doll may be opened to find another one inside it. This can be repeated several times, till a final doll -that cannot be opened- is reached.

<P>
Recently, Vladimir realized that the idea of nesting dolls might be generalized to nesting toys. Indeed, he has designed toys that contain toys but in a more general sense. One of these toys may be opened in two halves and it may have more than one toy inside it. That is the new feature that Vladimir wants to introduce in his new line of toys. 

<P>
Vladimir has developed a notation to describe how nesting toys should be constructed. A toy is represented with a positive integer, according to its size. More precisely: if when opening the toy represented by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> we find the toys represented by <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">...</SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>r</SUB></SPAN>, it must be true that <!-- MATH
 $n_1+ n_2+ \dots + n_r < m$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>1</SUB> + <I>n</I><SUB>2</SUB> + ... + <I>n</I><SUB>r</SUB> &lt; <I>m</I></SPAN>. And if this is the case, we say that toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> <SPAN  CLASS="textit">contains directly</SPAN> the toys <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">...</SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>r</SUB></SPAN> . It should be clear that toys that may be contained in any of the toys <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">...</SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><SUB>r</SUB></SPAN> are not considered as directly contained in the toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN>. 

<P>
A <I>generalized matrioshka</I> is denoted with a non-empty sequence of non zero integers of the form: <P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
a_1\quad a_2\quad \dots\quad a_N
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;...&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>a</I><SUB>N</SUB>
</DIV><P></P>
such that toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> is represented in the sequence with two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH">- <I>k</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>, with the negative one occurring in the sequence first that the positive one.  

<P>
For example, the sequence <P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
-9\quad -7\quad -2\quad 2\quad -3\quad -2\quad -1\quad 1\quad 2\quad 3\quad 7\quad 9
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
-9&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9
</DIV><P></P>
represents a generalized matrioshka conformed by six toys, namely, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">1</SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN> (twice), <SPAN CLASS="MATH">3</SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">7</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH">9</SPAN>. Note that toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH">7</SPAN> contains directly toys <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH">3</SPAN>. Note that the first copy of toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN> occurs left from the second one and that the second copy contains directly a toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH">1</SPAN>. It would be wrong to understand that the first <SPAN CLASS="MATH">-2</SPAN> and the last <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN> should be paired.

<P>
On the other hand, the following sequences do not describe generalized matrioshkas:

<UL>
<LI><P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
-9\quad -7\quad -2\quad 2\quad -3\quad -1\quad -2\quad 2\quad 1\quad 3\quad 7\quad 9
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
-9&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9
</DIV><P></P>
because toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN> is bigger than toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH">1</SPAN> and cannot be allocated inside it. 

<P>
</LI>
<LI><P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
-9\quad -7\quad -2\quad 2\quad -3\quad -2\quad -1\quad 1\quad 2\quad 3\quad 7\quad -2\quad 2\quad 9
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
-9&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9
</DIV><P></P>
because <SPAN CLASS="MATH">7</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN> may not be allocated together inside <SPAN CLASS="MATH">9</SPAN>.

<P>
</LI>
<LI><P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
-9\quad -7\quad -2\quad 2\quad -3\quad -1\quad -2\quad 3\quad 2\quad 1\quad 7\quad 9
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
-9&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;7&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9
</DIV><P></P>
because there is a nesting problem within toy <SPAN CLASS="MATH">3</SPAN>.

<P>
</LI>
</UL>

<P>
Your problem is to write a program to help Vladimir telling good designs from bad ones. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains several test cases, each one of them in a separate line. Each test case is a sequence of non zero integers, each one with an absolute value less than <SPAN CLASS="MATH">10<SUP>7</SUP></SPAN>.   

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Output texts for each input case are presented in the same order that input is read. 

<P>
For each test case the answer must be a line of the form

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<TT>:-) Matrioshka!</TT>

<P>

<P>
<BR>
if the design describes a generalized matrioshka. In other case, the answer should be of the form

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<TT>:-( Try again.</TT> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
-9 -7 -2 2 -3 -2 -1 1 2 3 7 9
-9 -7 -2 2 -3 -1 -2 2 1 3 7 9
-9 -7 -2 2 -3 -1 -2 3 2 1 7 9
-100 -50 -6 6 50 100
-100 -50 -6 6 45 100
-10 -5 -2 2 5 -4 -3 3 4 10
-9 -5 -2 2 5 -4 -3 3 4 9
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
		<PRE>
:-) Matrioshka!
:-( Try again.
:-( Try again.
:-) Matrioshka!
:-( Try again.
:-) Matrioshka!
:-( Try again.
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11112||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem C - Babylonian Roulette</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem C - Babylonian Roulette">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem C - Babylonian Roulette</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
<BLOCKQUOTE>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<SMALL CLASS="FOOTNOTESIZE">... Los babilonios se entregaron al juego. El que no adquiría suertes era considerado un pusilánime, un apocado. Con el tiempo, ese desdén justificado se duplicó. Era despreciado el que no jugaba, pero también eran despreciados los perdedores que abonaban la multa ...
</SMALL></DIV></BLOCKQUOTE>
<P>
<BLOCKQUOTE>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT"><SMALL CLASS="FOOTNOTESIZE"><SMALL CLASS="FOOTNOTESIZE">Jorge Luis Borges, La lotería de Babilonia, Ficciones

</SMALL></SMALL></DIV>
</BLOCKQUOTE>

<P>
People of Babylon were devoted to chance games and one of the most popular was a special kind of roulette. Recently, some old Babylonian tablets were found. They described details of the roulette game. 

<P>
In modern terms, the rules of the game were as follows:

<UL>
<LI>Roulette's compartments had only six labels: <TT>-1, -2, -3, 1, 2, 3</TT>.
</LI>
<LI>The game was played by turns, during a day. Turns were numerated <TT>0, 1, 2, ...</TT>
</LI>
<LI>Players could win or lose a multiple of the <SPAN  CLASS="textit">bet</SPAN>, a quantity of money that was constant along the day.
</LI>
<LI>At turn <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN> there was an amount of money <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>t</SUB></SPAN>, called the <SPAN  CLASS="textit">pot</SPAN>.
</LI>
<LI>At the start, there was an initial amount of money <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>0</SUB></SPAN> in the pot. 
</LI>
<LI><SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>0</SUB></SPAN> and the bet were positive numbers arbitrarily defined by the King. 
</LI>
<LI>In a turn, a player turned the roulette. A player could not play more than once in a day. Depending on the compartment where the ball came to rest, the player lose (or won, if the value was negative) an amount <!-- MATH
 $w_{t} = L * bet$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>w</I><SUB>t</SUB> = <I>L</I>*<I>bet</I></SPAN> of money, where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>L</I></SPAN> corresponded to the compartment's label.
</LI>
<LI>The won money was taken from the pot (or put in it if the player lose), i.e. the value of the pot in a given turn was determined by <!-- MATH
 $P_{t+1} = P_{t} + w_{t}$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>t+1</SUB> = <I>P</I><SUB>t</SUB> + <I>w</I><SUB>t</SUB></SPAN>.
</LI>
<LI>If as a result of the last rule <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>t+1</SUB></SPAN> was a negative number the winner won only the maximum multiple of the bet that he could win without making a negative pot.   
</LI>
<LI>If at some turn the pot was less than the bet, the game was ended for that day. If that was not the case the game continued till sunset.
</LI>
</UL> 

<P>
Beside the tablets that explained the rules some other tablets were found. These had lines with three  numbers. Archeologists conjecture that each of these lines were part of a kind of accountability system for the game, where numbers represented, for a given day, the value of the pot at the beginning, the bet and the value of the pot at the end.

<P>
For example, a line with the numbers
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<TT>10000 1500 11500</TT>

</DIV>

<P>
could mean that there was only one turn where the player lose with label <TT>1</TT>. Another possibility is that there were three turns with results <TT>2</TT>, <TT>1</TT> and <TT>-2</TT>. 

<P>
On the other hand, there were found other tablets with triplets of numbers that seem like the above described that, however, cannot represent results of a game day. There is no hypothesis of what they are.  

<P>
Archeologists want to validate their hypothesis analyzing batches of tablets with triplets. They want to 
estimate the number of people that played in a day. To begin, they want to establish, for each triplet of numbers in a tablet that could represent a result of a game day, the minimal number of players that played that day. In the above example the answer to this question is <TT>1</TT>. Tablets that cannot represent results should be identified. You are hired to help with this task.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains several test cases, each one of them in a separate line. 
Each test case is a triplet of non negative integers, indicating the initial pot, the bet and the final pot for a day. Each of the input numbers is less than <SPAN CLASS="MATH">10<SUP>8</SUP></SPAN>. The initial pot and the bet are greater than <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0</SPAN>. 

<P>
A line with a triplet of <TT>0</TT>'s denotes the end of the input.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Output texts for each input case are presented in the same order that input is read. For each test case the answer must be a printed line.

<P>
If the test case cannot represent the result of a game day, the output line has the words <TT>No accounting tablet</TT>. In other case, the printed answer is one positive integer number telling the minimal number of players that could turn the roulette for the day corresponding to the annotations. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
10000 1000 22000
24 13 2
5100 700 200
54 16 158
360 6 72
25 10 5
0 0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
		<PRE>
4
No accounting tablet
3
No accounting tablet
16
1
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________

  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem D - Continuous Fractions</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem D - Continuous Fractions">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem D - Continuous Fractions</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
A simple continuous fraction has the form: 
<P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
a_{1}+\frac{1}{a_{2}+{\displaystyle \frac{1}{a_{3}+{\displaystyle \frac{1}{\ddots+{\displaystyle \frac{1}{a_{n}}}}}}}}
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB> + <IMG
 WIDTH="156" HEIGHT="165" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11113img1.png" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle {\frac{{1}}{{a_{2}+{\displaystyle \frac{1}{a_{3}+{\displaystyle \frac{1}{\ddots+{\displaystyle \frac{1}{a_{n}}}}}}}}}}$">
</DIV><P></P>

<P>
where the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>'s are integer numbers. 

<P>
The previous continuous fraction could be noted as <!-- MATH
 $[a_{1},a_{2},\ldots,a_{n}]$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">[<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>,..., <I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB>]</SPAN>.
It is not difficult to show that any rational number <!-- MATH
 $\frac{p}{q}$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11113img1.png" 
 ALT="$ {\frac{{p}}{{q}}}$"></SPAN>,
with integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>p</I> &gt; <I>q</I> &gt; 0</SPAN>, can be represented in a unique way by a simple continuous fraction
with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> terms, such that <!-- MATH
 $\frac{p}{q}=[a_{1},a_{2},\ldots,a_{n-1},1]$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11113img1.png" 
 ALT="$ {\frac{{p}}{{q}}}$"> = [<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>,..., <I>a</I><SUB>n-1</SUB>, 1]</SPAN>,
where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> and the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>'s are positive natural numbers.

<P>
Your task is to find and print the simple continuous fraction that
corresponds to a given rational number.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input will consist of a series of cases, each one in a line. A line describing a case contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>p</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>q</I></SPAN>, two integer numbers separated by a space, with <!-- MATH
 $10^{20} > p > q > 0$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">10<SUP>20</SUP> &gt; <I>p</I> &gt; <I>q</I> &gt; 0</SPAN>.

<P>
The end of the input is indicated by a line containing <TT>0 0</TT>.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Cases must be analyzed in the order that are read from the input.
Output for each case will consist of several lines. The first line indicates the case number, starting at 1, using the  format:

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<TT>Case i:</TT> 

<P>

<P>
<BR>
replacing <TT>i</TT> by the corresponding case number. The second line displays the input data in the form
<TT>p / q</TT>.

<P>
The remaining lines must contain the continuous fraction corresponding
to the rational number, <!-- MATH
 $\frac{p}{q}$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="15" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11113img1.png" 
 ALT="$ {\frac{{p}}{{q}}}$"></SPAN>, specified in the given input
line. The continuous fraction must be printed accordingly to the following
rules:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>Horizontal bars are formed by sequences of dashes `<TT>-</TT>'.
</LI>
<LI>The width of each horizontal bar is exactly equal to the width of
the denominator under it.
</LI>
<LI>Blank characters should be printed using periods `<TT>.</TT>'
</LI>
<LI>The number on a fraction numerator must be printed center justified.
That is, the number of spaces at either side must be same, if possible;
in other case, one more space must be added at the right side.
</LI>
</UL>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
75 34
65 60
0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
		<PRE>
Case 1:
75 / 34
..........1......
2.+.-------------
............1....
....4.+.---------
..............1..
........1.+.-----
................1
............5.+.-
................1
Case 2:
65 / 60
......1...
1.+.------
.........1
....11.+.-
.........1
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11114||||||false||||||

original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem E - Polygon Encoder</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem E - Polygon Encoder">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem E - Polygon Encoder</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Imagine an infinite table with rows and columns numbered using the
natural numbers. The following figure shows a procedure to traverse
such a table assigning a consecutive natural number to each table
cell:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{table.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="300" HEIGHT="300" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{table.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
This enumeration of cells can be used to represent complex data types
using natural numbers:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>A pair of natural numbers <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>)</SPAN> is represented by the number corresponding
to the cell in row <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN> and column <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>j</I></SPAN>. For instance, the pair (3,2)
is represented by the natural number 17; this fact is noted by <!-- MATH
 $P_{2}(3,2)=17$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(3, 2) = 17</SPAN>.
</LI>
<LI>The pair representation can be used to represent <SPAN  CLASS="textit">n</SPAN>-tuples.
A triplet <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>a</I>, <I>b</I>, <I>c</I>)</SPAN> is represented by <!-- MATH
 $P_{2}(a,P_{2}(b,c))$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>a</I>, <I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>b</I>, <I>c</I>))</SPAN>. A 4-tuple
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>a</I>, <I>b</I>, <I>c</I>, <I>d</I> )</SPAN> is represented by <!-- MATH
 $P_{2}(a,P_{2}(b,P_{2}(c,d)))$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>a</I>, <I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>b</I>, <I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>c</I>, <I>d</I> )))</SPAN>. This
procedure can be generalized for an arbitrary <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>: <P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
P_{n}(a_{1},...,a_{n})=P_{2}(a_{1},P_{n-1}(a_{2},..,a_{n})),
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>P</I><SUB>n</SUB>(<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB>) = <I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>P</I><SUB>n-1</SUB>(<I>a</I><SUB>2</SUB>,.., <I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB>)),
</DIV><P></P>
where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>n</SUB></SPAN> denotes the <SPAN  CLASS="textit">n</SPAN>-tuple representation function,
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \ge$">2</SPAN>. For example <!-- MATH
 $P_{3}(2,0,1)=12$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I><SUB>3</SUB>(2, 0, 1) = 12</SPAN>.
</LI>
<LI>A list of arbitrary length <!-- MATH
 $\left\langle a_{1},...,a_{n}\right\rangle$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \left\langle\vphantom{ a_{1},...,a_{n}}\right.$"><I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \left.\vphantom{ a_{1},...,a_{n}}\right\rangle$"></SPAN> is represented by
<P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
L(\left\langle a_{1},...,a_{n}\right\rangle)=P_{2}(n,P_{n}(a_{1},...,a_{n})).
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>L</I>(<IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle \left\langle\vphantom{ a_{1},...,a_{n}}\right.$"><I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle \left.\vphantom{ a_{1},...,a_{n}}\right\rangle$">) = <I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>n</I>, <I>P</I><SUB>n</SUB>(<I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>,..., <I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB>)).
</DIV><P></P>
For example, <!-- MATH
 $L(\left\langle 0,1 \right\rangle)=12$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>L</I>(<IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \left\langle\vphantom{ 0,1 }\right.$">0, 1<IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \left.\vphantom{ 0,1 }\right\rangle$">) = 12</SPAN>.
</LI>
</UL>
The Association of Convex Makers (ACM) uses this clever enumeration
scheme in a polygon representation system. The system can represent
a polygon, defined by integer coordinates, using a natural number
as follows: given a polygon defined by a vertex sequence <!-- MATH
 $\left\langle (x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})\right\rangle$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \left\langle\vphantom{ (x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})}\right.$">(<I>x</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>1</SUB>),...,(<I>x</I><SUB>n</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>n</SUB>)<IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$ \left.\vphantom{ (x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})}\right\rangle$"></SPAN>
assign the natural number:<P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
L(\left\langle  P_{2}(x_{1},y_{1}),...,P_{2}(x_{n},y_{n})\right\rangle).
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>L</I>(<IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle \left\langle\vphantom{ P_{2}(x_{1},y_{1}),...,P_{2}(x_{n},y_{n})}\right.$"><I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>x</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>1</SUB>),..., <I>P</I><SUB>2</SUB>(<I>x</I><SUB>n</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>n</SUB>)<IMG
 WIDTH="13" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11114.jpg" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle \left.\vphantom{ P_{2}(x_{1},y_{1}),...,P_{2}(x_{n},y_{n})}\right\rangle$">).
</DIV><P></P>

<P>
ACM needs a program that, given a natural numbers that represents
a polygon, calculates the area of the polygon. It is guaranteed that
the given polygon is a simple one, i.e. its sides do not intersect.

<P>
As an example of the problem, the triangle with vertices at <TT>(1,1)</TT>,
<TT>(2,0)</TT> and <TT>(0,0)</TT> is codified with the number <TT>2141</TT>.
The area of this triangle is <TT>1</TT>.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input consists of several test cases. Each test case is given
in a single line of the input by a natural number representing a polygon.
The end of the test cases is indicated with <TT>*</TT>. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
One line per test case, preserving the input order. Each output line
contains a decimal number telling the area of the corresponding encoded
polygon. Areas must be printed with 1 decimal place, truncating less
significative decimal places.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
2141 
206 
157895330
*
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
		<PRE>
1.0 
0.5 
1.0
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11115||||||false||||||

  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem F - Uncle Jack</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem F - Uncle Jack">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem F - Uncle Jack</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Dear Uncle Jack is willing to give away some of his collectable CDs to his nephews. Among the titles you can find very rare albums of Hard Rock, Classical Music, Reggae and much more; each title is considered to be unique. Last week he was listening to one of his favorite songs, <I>Nobody's fool</I>, and realized that it would be prudent to be aware of the many ways he can give away the CDs among some of his nephews.

<P>
So far he has not made up his mind about the total amount of CDs and the number of nephews. Indeed, a given nephew may receive no CDs at all. 

<P>
Please help dear Uncle Jack, given the total number of CDs and the number of nephews, to calculate the number of different ways to distribute the CDs among the nephews. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input consists of several test cases. Each test case is given in a single line of the input by, space separated, integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1\le N \le 10$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11115img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11115img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10</SPAN>) and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>D</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le D \le 25$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11115img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>D</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/11115img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">25</SPAN>), corresponding to the number of nephews and the number of CDs respectively. The end of the test cases is indicated with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = <I>D</I> = 0</SPAN>.  

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The output consists of several lines, one per test case, following the order given by the input. Each line has the number of all possible ways to distribute <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>D</I></SPAN> CDs among <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> nephews. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
1 20
3 10
0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 

<P>
<PRE>
1
59049
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11116||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem G - Babel Towers</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem G - Babel Towers">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem G - Babel Towers</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Babel Inc. is a company that designs structures for skyscrapers. They have developed a simple technique to estimate the feasibility of a design, based on the fact that their designs are equivalent to stack blocks of circular section and constant height. The height of a block is used as the unit of lineal measure. 

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
<SPAN  CLASS="textit">Blocks</SPAN> are all made of the same non deformable uniform material, so that the weight of a block is proportional to its volume and its center of mass is the geometrical center of the block. A typical block is of the form

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">

<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{babel1.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="300" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{babel1.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
which weight is determined by the radius of the circular section (because every one has height <SPAN CLASS="MATH">1</SPAN>).

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
For <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \geq$"> 1</SPAN>, an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>-tower is a stack of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> blocks. Blocks in an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>-tower are numbered <!-- MATH
 $0,1, \dots , n-1\,$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0, 1,..., <I>n</I> - 1&nbsp;</SPAN>, from the bottom to the top. Given an <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>-tower, its <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-subtower is defined as the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-tower with the first <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> blocks of the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>-tower, <!-- MATH
 $0 \leq k < n\,$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \leq$"> <I>k</I> &lt; <I>n</I>&nbsp;</SPAN>. An example of a <SPAN CLASS="MATH">5</SPAN>-tower could look like the following figure:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">

<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{babel2.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="400"  ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{babel2.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
A tower is <SPAN  CLASS="textit">feasible</SPAN> when it can be built putting its blocks one by one from bottom to top. At each building step the corresponding subtower should be <SPAN  CLASS="textit">stable</SPAN>, i.e., every block of it must remain in the position that it is designed to stay. When placing a block results in a stack of blocks which part of it has a center of mass that lies out of the base on that it is supported we say that the resulting tower <SPAN  CLASS="textit">collapses</SPAN> and is <SPAN  CLASS="textit">unfeasible</SPAN>.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Babel Inc. does not consider stable a situation where the center of mass of the system of blocks that are supposed to rest on a block lies on the border of the supporting surface. For instance, two blocks of the same dimensions with one of them placed centered on the circumference of the other constitute a <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2</SPAN>-tower that collapses; but if the second one is placed within the circle of the first one the system is feasible.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Your problem is to help Babel Inc. in the evaluation of tower designs. Given a design for a <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>-tower you must judge if it is feasible and, if it is not, you must tell at which floor it would collapse. In this last case you give <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> as answer, with <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>k</I> &lt; <I>n</I></SPAN>, if the <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>k</I> - 1)</SPAN>-subtower is feasible but the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-subtower collapses.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains several test cases. 

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Each test case begins with a line indicating <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>N</I> &lt; 1000</SPAN>,  the number of blocks that the designed tower should have.  

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Then, there is a line describing each one of the blocks. The block <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $0 \leq k < N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \leq$"> <I>k</I> &lt; <I>N</I></SPAN>, is described by a line containing <SPAN CLASS="MATH">3</SPAN> integers separated by blanks, of the form <P><!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
x_k \; y_k \; r_k
\end{displaymath}
 -->
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>x</I><SUB>k</SUB> &nbsp;<I>y</I><SUB>k</SUB> &nbsp;<I>r</I><SUB>k</SUB>
</DIV><P></P>
which indicates that the block <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> with radius <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>k</SUB></SPAN> must be placed supported on the block <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I> - 1</SPAN> (exception: block <SPAN CLASS="MATH">0</SPAN> is placed on the ground) with its center of mass on the point <!-- MATH
 $\langle x_k,y_k,k+0.5 \rangle$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="11" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \langle$"><I>x</I><SUB>k</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>k</SUB>, <I>k</I> + 0.5<IMG
 WIDTH="11" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \rangle$"></SPAN> with respect to a grid with origin in <!-- MATH
 $\langle 0,0,0 \rangle\,$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><IMG
 WIDTH="11" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \langle$">0, 0, 0<IMG
 WIDTH="11" HEIGHT="35" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \rangle$">&nbsp;</SPAN>, for <!-- MATH
 $x_k , y_k \leq |10^5|$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I><SUB>k</SUB>, <I>y</I><SUB>k</SUB> <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \leq$"> | 10<SUP>5</SUP>|</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $1 \leq r_k \leq 10^5$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1 <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \leq$"> <I>r</I><SUB>k</SUB> <IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/111/p11116a.png" 
 ALT="$ \leq$"> 10<SUP>5</SUP></SPAN>. 

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
A case begin with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = 0</SPAN> means that there are no more cases to analyze.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Output texts for each input case are presented in the same order that input is read. 

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
For each test case the answer must be of the form `<TT>Feasible</TT>' if the design is feasible. In other case, the answer should be of the form `<TT>Unfeasible k</TT>' indicating that the <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>k</I> - 1)</SPAN>-subtower is feasible but the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN>-subtower is unfeasible.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
		<PRE>
3
0 0 10
2 0 12
-4 1 1
4
0 0 12
0 0 10
0 9 10
0 17 5
4
0 0 4
0 1 4
1 0 4
-1 -1 4
2
10 10 5
0 0 3
0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
		<PRE>
Feasible
Unfeasible 3
Feasible
Unfeasible 1
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11117||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2002-2-1 (1.71)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Problem H - Little Quilt</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Problem H - Little Quilt">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2002-2-1">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Problem H - Little Quilt</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
<SPAN  CLASS="textit">Little Quilt</SPAN> is a small language introduced by Ravi Sethi in
his book `Programming Languages'. Here, a restricted
version of Little Quilt is presented. 

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
The language is defined by the following BNF grammar:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TT>&lt;QUILT&gt; ::= A | B | turn(&lt;QUILT&gt;) | sew(&lt;QUILT&gt;,&lt;QUILT&gt;)</TT>
	
</DIV>

<P>
<TT>A</TT> and <TT>B</TT> represent the two primitive quilts. Each
primitive quilt corresponds to a matricial arrangement of <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2 <TT>x</TT> 2</SPAN>
characters. <TT>turn()</TT> and <TT>sew()</TT> are operations over
quilts. 

<P>
The instruction <TT>turn(x)</TT> turns the quilt <TT>x</TT> 90 degrees clockwise.
The following table illustrates the primitive quilts as well as examples of the effect of the <TT>turn()</TT> operation:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE COLS=2 BORDER FRAME=BOX RULES=GROUPS>
<COLGROUP><COLGROUP><COL ALIGN=CENTER><COL ALIGN=LEFT>
<TBODY>
<TR><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=CENTER NOWRAP>
			<TT>A</TT> </TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>//</TT></TD></TR>
<TR><TD></TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>/+</TT> </TD></TR>
</TBODY><TBODY>
<TR><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=CENTER NOWRAP><TT>turn(A)</TT> </TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>&#92;&#92;</TT></TD></TR>
<TR><TD></TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>+&#92;</TT></TD></TR>
</TBODY><TBODY>
<TR><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=CENTER NOWRAP><TT>turn(turn(A))</TT> </TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>+/</TT></TD></TR>
<TR><TD></TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>//</TT></TD></TR>
</TBODY><TBODY>
<TR><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=CENTER NOWRAP><TT>turn(turn(turn(A)))</TT> </TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>&#92;+</TT></TD></TR>
<TR><TD></TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>&#92;&#92;</TT></TD></TR>
</TBODY><TBODY>
<TR><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=CENTER NOWRAP><TT>B</TT> </TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>--</TT></TD></TR>
<TR><TD></TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>--</TT></TD></TR>
</TBODY><TBODY>
<TR><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=CENTER NOWRAP><TT>turn(B)</TT> </TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>||</TT></TD></TR>
<TR><TD></TD><TD VALIGN=BASELINE ALIGN=LEFT NOWRAP>  <TT>||</TT></TD></TR>
</TBODY>
</TABLE>

</DIV>

<P>
Accordingly, the instruction <TT>sew(x,y)</TT> sews quilt <TT>x</TT> to the left of quilt <TT>y</TT>. Both <TT>x</TT> and <TT>y</TT> must have the same height, otherwise an error will be generated. The following figure represents the result
of <TT>sew(A,turn(B))</TT>:

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TT>//||</TT> 
<BR>		<TT>/+||</TT>
	
</DIV>

<P>
while the <TT>sew(turn(sew(B,turn(B))),A)</TT> generates an error message.

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Your job is to build an interpreter of the Little Quilt language.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file will be a text file containing different Little Quilt expressions, each one ended by a semicolon character (;). Space and new line characters must be ignored; this means that an expression may span several lines.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The output file contains the quilts produced as a result of interpreting
the input expressions. 

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<P>
Each quilt must be preceded by a line, left aligned, with the format 

<P>
<TT>Quilt i:</TT> 

<P>
where <TT>i</TT> is the quilt number, starting at 1. If the expression interpretation generates and error, the word

<P>
<TT>error</TT> 

<P>
must be printed.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
sew(turn(sew(B,turn(B))), 
       turn(sew(turn(B),B)))   ; 
   
   
   sew(turn(sew(B,turn(B))),A); 
sew(turn(sew(A,turn(A))), 
 turn(turn(
   
   turn(sew(A,turn(A))))))
   
   ;
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2> 
		<PRE>
Quilt 1:
||--
||--
--||
--||
Quilt 2:
error
Quilt 3:
\\//
+\/+
+/\+
//\\
</PRE>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
XX Colombian National Programming Contest
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________

<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;

	mso-style-parent:" ;

	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;

 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="6146"/>
