<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem E</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Coin Collector</span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial'><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Input: </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Our dear Sultan is visiting a
country where there are <b>n</b> different types of coin. He wants to collect
as many different types of coin as you can. Now if he wants to withdraw <b>X</b>
amount of money from a Bank, the Bank will give him this money using following
algorithm.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>withdraw(X){<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:27.0pt;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>if( X == 0) return;<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:27.0pt;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Let Y be the highest valued coin that does
not exceed X.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:27.0pt;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Give the customer Y valued coin.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:27.0pt;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>withdraw(X-Y);<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>}<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Now Sultan can withdraw any amount
of money from the Bank. He should maximize the number of different coins that
he can collect in a single withdrawal.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Input:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>First line of the input contains
<b>T</b> the number of test cases. Each of the test cases starts with <b>n&nbsp;(1&#8804;n&#8804;1000)</b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>,</span> the number of different types of coin.
Next line contains n integers <b>C<sub>1</sub>,&nbsp;C<sub>2</sub>,&nbsp;...&nbsp;,&nbsp;C<sub>n</sub></b>
the value of each coin type. <b>C<sub>1</sub>&lt;C<sub>2</sub>&lt;C<sub>3</sub>&lt;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&lt;C<sub>n</sub>&lt;1000000000</b>.
<b>C<sub>1</sub></b> equals to 1.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Output:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:63.0pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>For each test case output one
line denoting the maximum number of coins that Sultan can collect in a single
withdrawal. He can withdraw infinite amount of money from the Bank.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=621
 style='width:465.4pt;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;height:14.7pt'>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:14.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:14.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes;height:84.3pt'>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:84.3pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>1 2 4 8 16 32<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>1 3 6 8 15 20<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:84.3pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>4<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

-->
</style>
<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */
 table.MsoNormalTable
	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-ansi-language:#0400;
	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
table.MsoTableGrid
	{mso-style-name:"Table Grid";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
	mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-border-insideh:.5pt solid windowtext;
	mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-ansi-language:#0400;
	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
</style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="3074"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem F</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><span class=GramE><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-size:20.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>The</span></b></span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
24.0pt;font-family:Arial'> Sultans Problem</span></b><span style='font-family:
Arial'><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Input: </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Once upon a time, there lived a great
sultan, who was very much fond of his wife. He wanted to build a <span
class=SpellE>Tajmahal</span> for his wife (<span class=SpellE>ya</span>, our
sultan idolized <span class=SpellE>Mughal</span> emperor <span class=SpellE>Shahjahan</span>).
But alas, due to budget cuts, loans, dues and many <span class=SpellE>many</span>
things, he had no fund to build something so big. So, he decided to build a
beautiful garden, inside his palace.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The garden is a rectangular piece
of land. All the palaces water lines run through the garden, thus, dividing it
into pieces of varying shapes. He wanted to cover each piece of the land with
flowers of same kind. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;page-break-after:avoid'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
 id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
 path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:6in;
 height:279pt'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/sultan_files/image001.png"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=576 height=372
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/sultan_files/image001.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]></p>

<p class=MsoCaption align=center style='text-align:center'>Figure <!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>SEQ Figure \* ARABIC <span style='mso-element:
field-separator'></span><![endif]--><span style='mso-no-proof:yes'>1</span><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The figure above shows a sample
flower garden. All the lines are straight lines, with two end points on two
different edge of the rectangle. Each piece of the garden is covered with the
same kind of flowers.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The garden has a small fountain,
located at position (<span class=SpellE><b>x</b><span class=GramE>,<b>y</b></span></span>).
You can assume that, it is not on any of the lines. He wants to fill that piece
with her <span class=SpellE>favourite</span> flower. So, he asks you to find
the area of that piece.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Input contains around 500 test
cases. Each case starts with 5 integers, <b>N</b>, <b>W</b>, <b>H</b>, <b>x</b>,
<b>y</b>, the number of lines, width and height of the garden and the location
of the fountain. Next <b>N</b> lines each contain 4 integers, <b>x<sub>1</sub>
y<sub>1</sub> x<sub>2</sub> y<sub>2</sub></b>, the two end points of the line.
The end points are always on the boundary of the garden. You can assume that,
the fountain is not located on any line.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For each test case, output the
case number, with the area of the piece covered with her <span class=SpellE>favourite</span>
flower. Print 3 digits after the decimal point.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Constraints<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0in' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>1 &#8804; W, H &#8804; 200,000</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo3;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>1 &#8804; N &#8804; 500</li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;height:27.4pt'>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:27.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:27.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'>3 100 <span class=SpellE>100</span> 20 30<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'>0 <span class=SpellE>0</span> 100 <span
  class=SpellE>100</span><o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'>100 0 <span class=SpellE>0</span> 100<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'>0 40 <span class=SpellE>40</span> 100<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'>Case #1: 1780.000<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem G</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Equations</span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial'><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Input: </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Find the number of solutions, the equation <b>&#8721;X<sub>i</sub>
= s</b> have, if <b>A<sub>i</sub>&#8804;X<sub>i</sub>&#8804;B<sub>i </sub></b>for
each <b>i = 1
n.</b><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>For example,<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>X<sub>1</sub>
+ X<sub>2</sub> + X<sub>3</sub> = 10<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>-1 &#8804;
X<sub>1 </sub>&#8804; 3<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>2 &#8804; X<sub>2
</sub>&#8804; 4<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>6 &#8804; X<sub>3
</sub>&#8804; 7<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>The above set of equations has 6 solutions. They are: {1,4,7},
{0,3,7}, {0,4,6}, {1,2,7}, {1,3,6} and {2,2,6}.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>You are given <b>n</b> the number of variables and the range
of them. Your task is to calculate the number of solutions of that equation.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Input:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>First line of the Input contains <b>T (&#8804;50)</b> the
number of test cases. Then <b>T</b> test cases follow. First line of each test
case contains 2 integer <b>n (1&#8804;n&#8804;10) </b>and <b>s (-50000 &#8804; s
&#8804; 50000)</b>. <span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>Next <b>n</b> lines each
contain 2 integers describing the range of each variable. The i<sup>th</sup>
line <b>A<sub>i</sub></b> and <b>B<sub>i </sub>(&#8209;10000 &#8804; A<sub>i</sub>
&#8804; B<sub>i</sub> &#8804;10000)</b>. <b>X<sub>i</sub></b> can take any
integral value in the range <b>[A<sub>i</sub>, B<sub>i</sub>].</b><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Output:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>For each test case output contains one integer denoting the
number of solutions of the given equations. Output the value <b>modulo 200003</b>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=621
 style='width:465.4pt;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;height:14.7pt'>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:14.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:14.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes;height:84.3pt'>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:84.3pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>3 10<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>-1 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>2 4<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>6 7<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:84.3pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<title>The Hire-a-Coder business model</title>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem H</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:20.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>The Hire-a-Coder Business Model</span></b><span style='font-family:
Arial'><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Input: </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>As some other websites, Hire-a-Coder
is a new website that works as an agent between custom software buyers &amp;
freelance software developers. According to the Hire-a-Coder business model,
a number of clients are registered in the system. Some of them are software
buyers. They post custom software projects on the site. Then the coders bid on
the projects &amp; each of the projects is assigned to a single particular coder
after the biddings &amp; dealings. Any buyer may have more than one open
project at a time. Similarly any coder can take up more than a single project
at any time. But no coder is allowed to take multiple projects from the same
buyer at a time. The site works as a medium in the total procedure. Now, if a
coder successfully completes his assigned project &amp; the buyer accepts his
work, Hire-a-Coder gets some commission for that. But if the coder fails to
complete a project or satisfy the client with his work, the company has to pay
a penalty to the buyer thus suffering a loss. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Recently it is found out that
there are a number of fake coders that take up a project but never finish their
work eventually causing the company a good amount of loss. So, they need someone
to advise them which of the possible project assignments are to make &amp;
which are to avoid in order to minimize their loss.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Assume, all the registered
clients of the company are denoted by a unique positive integer number between
1 &amp; N. By the help of a great fortune-teller, they have already tabulated
the future of assigning all possible buyer-coder pairs. You can assume that
assigning any project from a particular buyer to a particular coder has the
same future. In their tabulation, if a coder fails to do a project from a
buyer, a positive integer value is assigned to this particular buyer-coder
pair. The value indicates the amount of loss the company is going to suffer if
they pair-up these two clients. On the other hand, in case of a successful completion
of a project from a buyer-coder pair, a negative integer value is assigned to
this pair which denotes negative loss i.e. amount of profit.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>You are assured that, every
single individual in the community has a communication link to all other people
in this community, not necessarily through direct acquaintance. The link may
well be via one or more other people. Also note that, if A knows B then B
always knows A.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Theres one more problem. You
have the pairing information for all those N people but you dont know which of
them are buyers &amp; which of them are coders. But you know that, all the
registered clients are either a buyer or a coder &amp; theres no one who is a
buyer &amp; a coder simultaneously. If the data for any test case violates this
assumption, print <b>Invalid data, Idiot!</b> &amp; stop processing that case
further.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Now, bearing all these factors in
mind, you are to select a subset of the possible pairings so that if the
company makes strictly those assignments, their loss is minimum possible. Also,
you have to choose the subset so that every single person still has a direct /
indirect communication link to all other people. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Every test case starts with a
single positive integer <b>N</b> (<b>2&lt;=N&lt;=200</b>) which is the number
of registered clients. The second line has another positive integer <b>E</b> (<b>1&lt;=N&lt;=11000</b>),
the number of pairs tabulated by the fortune-teller. Each of the next <b>E</b>
lines contains 3 integers <b>A</b>,<b>B</b> &amp; <b>C</b> which means, if the
company pairs A with B, they will end up in a<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>loss with amount C. (<b>1&lt;=A,B&lt;=N</b> and <b>-1000&lt;=C&lt;=1000</b>).
The last test case will be followed immediately by a single line containing a
0. This line indicates the end of file.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>If the there is any inconsistency
in the data (as described in the statement) print <b>Invalid data, Idiot! </b>in
a single line. Otherwise, print the minimum possible loss the company can
afford without disconnecting the social network.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>9<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 4 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 4 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 4 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 5 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 5 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 5 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 6 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 6 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 6 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>10<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 2 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 4 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 4 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 4 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 5 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 5 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 5 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 6 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 6 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3 6 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>4<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>4<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 3 5<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>1 4 -3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 3 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>2 4 -6<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>8<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Invalid data,
  Idiot!<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>-7<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Problemsetter: </b>Mohammad Mahmudur Rahman</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Special Thanks To: </b>Manzurur Rahman Khan</p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

<title>Problem I</title>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem I</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Reliable Network</span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial'><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Input: </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>A network has <b>n</b> routers,
uniquely numbered from 1 to n. Two routers can communicate with each other, if
either they are directly connected, or one of them is connected with someone,
that can communicate with the other (indirectly connected). Now, connect these
n routers in such a way that after any <b>m</b> routers become inactive all
other active routers can communicate among each other directly or through a
series of active routers. But the number of connections should not exceed <b>ceil
(((m+1)*n)/2)</b>. All the communication links are bidirectional.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Input:<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>First line of the input contains
T the number of test cases. Each test case contains 2 integers in one line <span
class=GramE>n(</span>1&#8804;n&#8804;50) and m(1&#8804;m&#8804;10 and m&lt;(n-2)).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Output:<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For each test case output should
contain e+2 lines where e is the number of connections needed. First line
contains e. line 2 to e+1 contains 2 integers i and j denoting that there
should be a connection between the router i and router j. line e+2 is blank. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>4 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=295 valign=top style='width:221.4pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>4<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>1 2<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>2 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>3 4<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'>4 1<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  Vrinda'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=windows-1252">

<link rel=File-List href="j_files/filelist.xml">

w\:* {behavior:url(#default#VML);}
.shape {behavior:url(#default#VML);}
</style>
<![endif]-->
<title>As you see, setting problems for a programming contest is a tough job</title>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:DocumentProperties>
  <o:Author>Mahmudur Rahman</o:Author>
  <o:LastAuthor>Shahriar Manzoor</o:LastAuthor>
  <o:Revision>2</o:Revision>
  <o:TotalTime>57</o:TotalTime>
  <o:Created>2007-08-29T06:09:00Z</o:Created>
  <o:LastSaved>2007-08-29T06:09:00Z</o:LastSaved>
  <o:Pages>1</o:Pages>
  <o:Words>292</o:Words>
  <o:Characters>1666</o:Characters>
  <o:Company>EEE, BUET</o:Company>
  <o:Lines>13</o:Lines>
  <o:Paragraphs>3</o:Paragraphs>
  <o:CharactersWithSpaces>1955</o:CharactersWithSpaces>
  <o:Version>11.5606</o:Version>
 </o:DocumentProperties>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <w:WordDocument>
  <w:GrammarState>Clean</w:GrammarState>
  <w:PunctuationKerning/>
  <w:ValidateAgainstSchemas/>
  <w:SaveIfXMLInvalid>false</w:SaveIfXMLInvalid>
  <w:IgnoreMixedContent>false</w:IgnoreMixedContent>
  <w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>false</w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>
  <w:Compatibility>
   <w:BreakWrappedTables/>
   <w:SnapToGridInCell/>
   <w:WrapTextWithPunct/>
   <w:UseAsianBreakRules/>
   <w:UseWord2002TableStyleRules/>
  </w:Compatibility>
  <w:BrowserLevel>MicrosoftInternetExplorer4</w:BrowserLevel>
 </w:WordDocument>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <w:LatentStyles DefLockedState="false" LatentStyleCount="156">
 </w:LatentStyles>
</xml><![endif]-->
<style>
<!--

	{mso-style-parent:" ;
	margin:0in;
	margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:12.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";}
span.GramE
	{mso-style-name:" ;
	mso-gram-e:yes;}

	{size:595.45pt 841.7pt;
	margin:1.0in 1.0in 1.0in 1.0in;
	mso-header-margin:.5in;
	mso-footer-margin:.5in;
	mso-paper-source:0;}
div.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
-->
</style>
<!--[if gte mso 10]>
<style>
 /* Style Definitions */

	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	mso-style-noshow:yes;
	mso-style-parent:" ;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-ansi-language:#0400;
	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
table.MsoTableGrid
	{mso-style-name:"Table Grid";
	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;
	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;
	border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
	mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
	mso-border-insideh:.5pt solid windowtext;
	mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext;
	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-ansi-language:#0400;
	mso-fareast-language:#0400;
	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}

<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="2050"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Problem J</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:20.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:
Arial'>Setting Problems<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Input: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>As you see, setting problems for
a programming contest is a tough job. There are so many things to do like
creating problems, solutions, data files, verification of problem statements,
writing alternate judge solutions etc. etc. Given the responsibility of
creating the problemset for If you can not crash judges by solutions, crash
contestants by problems programming contest, Sultan &amp; GolapiBaba have
realized that to the backbone. Finally they agree that they will set <b>N</b>
problems for the contest. For each of the problems, first Sultan will create
the problem statement, solution &amp; <span class=GramE>i/o</span> data. After
he finishes his work, GolapiBaba does the verification &amp; alternate solution
writing part for that particular problem. Each of them needs a particular
amount of time to complete their tasks for a certain problem. Also, none of
them works on more than one problem at a time. Note that, GolapiBaba can start
working on a problem immediately after Sultan finishes that problem or he may
wish to start that problem later. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>You will be given the times that Sultan
&amp; GolapiBaba requires to complete their respective tasks for every single
problem. Determine the minimum possible time required to complete the whole
problemset.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>There are around 50 test cases. Each
test case starts with a single integer <b>N</b> (<b>1&lt;=N&lt;=20</b>), the
number of problems in the contest. The next line contains <b>N</b> integers <b>S<sub>i</sub></b><sub>
</sub>(<b>1&lt;=S<sub>i</sub>&lt;=100</b>,&nbsp;<b>1&lt;=i&lt;=N</b>) where <b>Si</b>
denotes the time required for Sultan to complete his tasks for problem i. The next
line has <b>N</b> more integers <b>G<sub>i</sub></b> (<b>1&lt;=G<sub>i</sub>&lt;=100</b>,
<b>1&lt;=i&lt;=N</b>) where <b>G<sub>i</sub></b> denotes the time required for
Golapibaba to complete his tasks on problem i.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Output<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For each test case, print the
minimum time required to complete the problemset.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=621
 style='width:465.4pt;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;height:14.05pt'>

  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=310 valign=top style='width:232.7pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;

  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:14.05pt'>

  </td>

11270||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Tiling Dominoes</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">A. Tiling Dominoes</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">Problem</A></FONT></H2>


<P>Given a rectangular grid, with dimensions <b>m x n</b>, compute the number of ways of completely
tiling it with dominoes.  Note that if the rotation of one tiling matches another, they still
count as different ones.  A domino is a shape formed by the union of two unit squares meeting edge-to-edge. 
Equivalently, it is a matching in the grid graph formed by placing a vertex at 
the center of each square of the region and connecting two vertices when they correspond to adjacent squares.  An
example of a tiling is shown below.<p>

<H1 ALIGN=center>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/p11270.gif"  width="300" height="300" border="8">
</H1>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will consist of a set of lines with <b>m n</b>, given the restriction <b>n*m<101</b>.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each line of input, output the number of tilings in a separate line.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
2 10
4 10
8 8
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
89
18061
12988816
</PRE>
</BODY>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao
<br />
Alternative Solution: Rodrigo Burgos
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11271||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Lattice of Resistors</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;
<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">B. Lattice of Resistors</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
Given an infinite 2D Lattice of resisters as shown below, where the resistance
on each edge between neighboring junctions is exactly <b>1</b>.  Pick any junction <b>O</b> and 
assign the coordinate <b>(0,0)</b>.  What is the total resistance between <b>O</b> and some
other junction <b>J=(i,j)</b>? 
<p>
<b>Hint:</b> <it>There is a surprising Dynamic Programming solution, but how do you get it to
fit under the memory requirement? :-) </it>. 

<H1 ALIGN=center>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/p11271.gif"  width="600" height="500" border="0">
</H1>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
A number of inputs.  One testcase on each line.
The input of each test case is simply the values <b>i</b>, <b>j</b> on a single line. 
All values will fit inside an unsigned 64 bit integer.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each input value, output the total resistance between <b>O</b> and <b>J</b>
 on a single line. Round to 3 digits after the decimal.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
0 0
0 1
0 2
0 3
0 4
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
0.000
0.500
0.727
0.861
0.954
</PRE>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao<br />
Alternative Solution: Mike Liu
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11272||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Summing The Lengths of Longest Increasing Subsequences of Permutations</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;
<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">C. Summing The Lengths of Longest Increasing Subsequences of Permutations</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>Compute the sum of the lengths of the longest increasing subsequence of each distinct permutation of <B>(1,2,3,..,n).</B><p>
In other words, sum over all permutations, <B>w</B> of <B>(1,2,3,..,n)</B>, <B>LIS(w)</B>.  Where <B>LIS(w)</B> is the length of the longest 
increasing subsequence of <B>w</B>.   However, this number increases  exponentially.  In the problem we are interested only 
in the first three digits.  Also, note that each subsequence does not have to be contiguous.  
For example, the longest increasing subsequence of (3,2,4,1,5) is (3,4,5) with length 3.  
<p><B>Hint:</B> You may want to compute a few small values and find a beautiful pattern!!!<p>
<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will consist of at most 100000 lines, each one with just the positive integer <B>n</B> (100<<B>n</B><100000000).

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each input value, output the first three digits of the 
sum of the lengths of the longest increasing subsequence of each permuation of (1,2,3,...,<B>n</B>).

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
101
1101
2101
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
154
358
905
</PRE>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao<br />
Alternative Solution: Mike Liu
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11273||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Warping of N Dimensional Space</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;
<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">D. Warping of N Dimensional Space</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>

In this problem, we want to apply a linear transformation to warp an <b>N</b> dimensional volume.  
Let <b>Volume(v)</b> denote the volume of the <b>N</b> dimensional parallelepiped 
spanned by <b>N</b>, <b>N</b> dimensional vectors <b>{v<sub>1</sub>,v<sub>2</sub>,...,v<sub>N</sub>}</b>.  
An example of a 2D volume spanned by 2, 2 dimensional vectors is shown below.
In a strange twist, we have decided to apply a "Linear GCD" 
transformation.  That is, if we represent our linear transformation <b>f:R<sup>N</sup>->R<sup>N</sup></b>  
by the matrix <b>A</b>, where <b>R</b> denotes the set of real numbers, then <b>A</b>(i,j) = <b>gcd</b>(i,j) 
for 1 <= i,j <= N, where <b>gcd</b>(i,j) stands for the greatest common divisor of i and j.
Given, <b>S</b>, any set of <b>N</b> vectors of <b>R<sup>N</sup></b>, such that <b>Volume(S)</b> is positive,
we ask you to compute the ratio of the volume after the transformation to the volume 
before the GCD Transformation.  In other words, compute <b>r(S)=Volume(F(S))/Volume(S)</b>,
where <b>F(S)={f(v) | v in S}</b>.
However, since <b>r(S)</b> can be quite large, we only ask you to compute 
<b>T(S)=floor(r(S)) mod  4000039</b>.  In an even stranger twist, we will not give you <b>S</b>,
but instead ask you to compute, the mean value of <b>T(S)</b> over
all <b>N</b> vectors <b>S</b> of <b>R<sup>N</sup></b>, such that  <b>Volume(S)</b> is positive.

<H1 ALIGN=center>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/p11273.gif"  width="600" height="500" border="0">
</H1>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input of each test cases is simply the value <b>N</b>(<b>N</b><4000000) on its own line.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each input value, output the answer rounded to an integer, followed by a newline.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
10000
10001
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
2747606
295638
</PRE>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao<br />
Alternative Solution: Mike Liu
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11274||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Infinite Resistor Network</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;
<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">E. Infinite Resistor Network</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
First, we begin with a square of side length <b>L</b>.  Connect the centers of each side to form another square. Connect the centers
of each side of this square to form yet another square, and so on, to infinity.  Suppose now that all the lines
in the diagram are uniform wires.  Let the resistance of a piece of wire of the Length <b>L</b> (length of a side of the outer most square)
be exactly <b>1</b>.  Let the net resistance between the points <b>A</b> and <b>B</b> be <b>R</b>.  
Compute the <b>k</b>-th digit after the decimal point of the value <b>R</b>.   Namely, let

 <b>R</b>=0.n<sub>1</sub>n<sub>2</sub>n<sub>3</sub>...n<sub><b>k</b></sub>...

Given <b>k</b>, output n<sub><b>k</b></sub>.


<H1 ALIGN=center>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/p11274.gif"  width="600" height="500" border="0">
</H1>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input of each test cases is simply the value <b>k</b> (<b>k</b><10000000 , 0 < min(k,990*10<sup>4</sup>-k) < 10<sup>4</sup>) on its own line.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each input value, output the <b>k</b>-th digit of <b>R</b> on a single line.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
2
4
6
9899898
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
5
9
8
4
</PRE>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao<br />
Alternative Solution: Mike Liu
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11275||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>3D Triangles</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;
<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">F. 3D Triangles</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
Given the vertices of two triangles in 3D Coordinates, check whether both of them have any common point. 
All points on the edges or vertices are considered to be part of the a triangle.  Two points are
considered to be the same point if their Euclidean distance is less or equal to 0.000001.

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
Input starts with an integer t (t<= 100000) denoting the number of test cases to follow.
Each test case contains 18 floating point numbers with at most 7 digits after the decimal.
They are the vertices of the triangles as (x, y , z). First three triples are for one triangle and rest of them are for 
the other one. None of the triangles will be invalid.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each input value, output <b>1</b> on a single line if the triangles share a common
point.  Otherwise, output <b>0</b>.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
2
0.366955 0.566515 0.398724
0.573168 0.175512 0.873745
0.705588 0.374035 0.072390
0.292306 0.515061 0.371929
0.623737 0.169012 0.514115
0.839076 0.717612 0.255867
0.039521 0.379528 0.617084
0.759484 0.836268 0.097446
0.594165 0.484085 0.191534
0.283731 0.896054 0.182867
0.443800 0.472579 0.899808
0.473342 0.573901 0.769219
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
1
0
</PRE>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao<br />
Alternative Solution: Mike Liu
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11276||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Magical Seven</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">G. Magical Seven</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">Problem</A></FONT></H2>


<P><b>7</b> is a very special number.  It is the smallest number that can't be represented as a sum of fewer than four non-zero squares.
It is also the smallest happy number greater than 1.  <b>7</b> is considered to be magical in many cultures.  In this problem,
you will discover the amazing hidden magic of <b>7</b> in graph theory :-).
<P>
Given a grid graph <b>G</b>, with dimensions <b>7 x n</b>, as shown below (the vertices are at the center of the grid cells).  
Compute the last 4 digits of <b>A</b>+<b>B</b>+<b>C</b>, where
<P>
<b>A</b> = The total number of different Perfect matchings of <b>G</b>.  A Perfect matching is a matching which covers all vertices of <b>G</b>.
<P>
<b>B</b> = The total number of different Hamiltonian cycles of <b>G</b>.  A Hamiltonian cycle visits each vertex exactly once and comes back to the original vertex.
<P>
<b>C</b> = The total number of different Spanning subgraphs of <b>G</b>, such that every connected component of each Spanning subgraph is a cycle.

<H1 ALIGN=center>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/p11276.gif"  width="395" height="116" border="0">
</H1>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will consist of at most 100 lines with the value of <b>n</b> on each line.  All numbers fit into unsigned 64 bit integers.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each line of input, output the answer on a single line.  If there are fewer than 4 digits in <b>A</b>+<b>B</b>+<b>C</b>, pad to
4 digits with leading 0's, otherwise output the last 4 digits as described above.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
1
2
6
10
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
0000
0030
5900
5765
</PRE>
</BODY>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao
Alternative Solution: Mike Liu
<br />
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11277||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Cyclic Polygons</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;
<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">H. Cyclic Polygons</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>

<H1 ALIGN=center>
<IMG SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/112/p11277.gif"  width="300" height="300" border="0">
</H1>
<CENTER>A Cyclic Hexagon</CENTER>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
A <it>Cyclic Polygon</it> is a polygon where all of its vertices lie on a circle.  Note that all triangles
are cyclic polygons.  The area of a triangle can be found from the lengths of its three sides using
Heron's formula.  It has been conjectured by D.P. Robins that Heron's formula can be generalized to all cyclic polygons.
Namely, the area of all cyclic polygons can be written as a polynomial equation involving only its side lengths.
In this problem, we will ask you to approximate the area of a Cyclic Polygon, given only its side lengths.
Of course, if you do find the closed form solution, don't forget to mention the problem-setter when you win
the Fields Medal :-).

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
Input starts with an integer <b>t</b> (<b>t</b> < 10001) on a line denoting the number of test cases to follow.
Each test case starts with a line with the integer <b>n</b> (<b>n</b> < 51), followed by <b>n</b>  lines
with the side lengths of the polygon, given in arbitrary order.
All side lengths are floating point numbers with at most 3 digits after the dicimal.  The sum
of the lengths of each polygon does not exceed 1000.000, and each side is always positive (>0).

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each case, output the area of the polygon <b>P</b> rounded to 3 digits after the decimal.
If the polygon is not valid, i.e. degenerate, output <b>"0.000"</b> without the quotes. 



<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
1
3
3.000
4.000
5.000
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
6.000
</PRE>
</div>
<br />

<hr size="1" />
Problem setter: Josh Bao<br />
Alternative Solution: Wenyuan Chen 
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11278||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<title>Problem A: One-Handed Typist</title>
</head>
<body>

<center>
<h1>Problem A</h1>
<h1>ONE-HANDED TYPIST</h1>
</center>

<p>Recently, a programming contest coach had a terrible accident and broke his left arm.
It was then that he discovered how dificult it was to type with only one hand.
He really needed to find a way to increase his typing speed,
since he had to create problems in a hurry for an upcoming programming contest.</p>

<p>His solution was to switch from the standard QWERTY keyboard layout to a right-handed
 Dvorak keyboard layout (see diagrams below). 
 It is pretty easy on a modern machine to change the keyboard layout in software,
  so that striking a key on the standard keyboard would give you the character
   at that position on the desired layout, whether or not it matches the physically
labeled character.</p>

<p align=center><img src=p11278a.png></p>

<p align=center><em>The standard QWERTY keyboard layout, shift-modified on right.</em></p>

<p align=center><img src=p11278b.png></p>

<p align=center><em>The right-handed Dvorak keyboard layout, shift-modified on right.</em></p>

<p>One day, as the coach was typing out a problem statement with his right hand,
he discovered that he had forgotten to change the keyboard layout from QWERTY
to Dvorak on the machine! Naturally, all the text came out scrambled, 
because he had struck the keys as if it were a right-handed Dvorak keyboard.
Alas, it would take too much time to retype all the text with only one hand.</p>
   
<p>Can you write a program to help the coach salvage his text?</p>

<h2>Input</h2>
<p>The input file consists of several lines of text,
representing the text typed by the coach on a QWERTY keyboard
layout when he thought he was using a right-handed Dvorak layout.
Each line contains no more than 1000 alphanumeric characters,
spaces, and punctuation found on the keyboard.</p>

<h2>Output</h2>
<p>For each line in the input,
your program should write the line of text that the coach had meant to type.
In other words, output the text as if it had been keyed using a right-handed
 Dvorak layout.</p>

<h2>Sample Input</h2>
<pre>
Hg66t Mty6k!
Jhg 4ibl; pytmn 8tc 5i79urrr
t,gy jhg 6fxo kt.r
</pre>

<h2>Output for the Sample Input</h2>
<pre>
Hello World!
The quick brown fox jumps...
over the lazy dog.
</pre>

<hr>
<i>Sonny Chan</i><br>
<i>Calgary Collegiate Programming Contest 2006</i><br />
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11279||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<title>Problem B: Keyboard Comparison</title>
</head>
<body>

<center>
<h1>Problem B</h1>
<h1>KEYBOARD COMPARISON</h1>
</center>

<p>After spending several weeks typing using the right-handed Dvorak keyboard layout,
the coach (introduced in the previous problem) started to wonder if it really is
 any better. He decided to devise a method to verify this.</p>
 
<p>The coach would like to compare typing on the right-handed Dvorak keyboard against
using a QWERTY keyboard with two hands and with one hand.
A crude, but effective way to compare keyboard layouts is to measure the total
distance the typing fingers must travel in order to type a certain passage of text.
Can you write a program to help the coach perform this experiment?</p>

<p>The distance travelled by a finger will be measured from the centre
of its home key to the centre of the target key and back.
In order to simplify the computations, we pretend that every key is a perfect square
with unit length sides, and that all keys are laid out on a perfect grid
(even though in reality they are usually staggered).
The diagrams below show the straightened keyboards; see the previous problem for
shift-modified diagrams.</p>

<p align=center><img src=p11279.png></p>

<p align=center><em>The QWERTY and right!handed Dvorak keyboard layouts arranged on perfect grids.</em></p>

<p>On the QWERTY keyboard, the home keys are "ASDFJKL;" for two hands and "FGHJ"
for one hand. On the Dvorak keyboard, the home keys are "EHTD".
A key is always struck by the finger from the nearest home key.</p>

<p>For example, the distances for 'S' would be 0, 4, and 2 for the two-hand QWERTY, 
one-hand QWERTY, and Dvorak keyboards, respectively. 
Likewise, the distances for 'C' would be 2, 2.828427..., and 2, respectively.</p>

<p>Given a line of text, your task is to compute the total distance travelled
by the typing fingers in typing that text, first using the QWERTY keyboard
with two hands, then with one hand, and finally using the right-handed Dvorak keyboard.
You can neglect any distance travelled in typing spaces or shifting.</p>

<h2>Input</h2>
<p>The input file consists of several lines of text. Each line contains no more than 1000
alpha-numeric characters, spaces, and punctuation found on the keyboard.</p>

<h2>Output</h2>
<p>For each line of input, your program should write a line containing three real
numbers accurate to 2 decimal places,
representing the total distances travelled by the typing fingers. 
The first number corresponds to using the QWERTY layout with two hands,
the second to one-handed QWERTY, and the third to right-handed Dvorak.</p>

<h2>Sample Input</h2>
<pre>
CCPC
Which keyboard is better?
Numbers! 1234567890
</pre>

<h2>Output for the Sample Input</h2>
<pre>
8.00 14.81 10.47
40.14 60.24 39.43
58.60 74.72 92.52
</pre>

<hr>
<i>Sonny Chan</i><br>
<i>Calgary Collegiate Programming Contest 2006</i><br />
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11280||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
<title>Problem C: Flying to Fredericton</title>
</head>
<body>

<center>
<h1>Problem C</h1>
<h1>FLYING TO FREDERICTON</h1>
</center>

<p>After being inspired by Salvador Dali's artwork, Brett decided he would like to travel to 
Fredericton, New Brunswick to visit the Beaverbrook Art Gallery.</p>

<p>Brett lives in Calgary, and would like to find the cheapest flight or flights that would take
him to Fredericton. He knows that a direct flight from Calgary to Fredericton, if one exists,
would be absurdly expensive, so he is willing to tolerate a certain number of stopovers.
However, there are multiple airlines in Canada with so many different flights between 
different cities now, which makes it very difficult for Brett to find the least expensive way to
Fredericton! Can you write a program to help Brett plan his route?</p>

<p align=center><img src=p11280.png></p>

<p align=center><em>Map showing a sample of the flights that would take Brett to Fredericton.</em></p>

<p>You will be given a list of cities between and including Calgary and Fredericton. The cities
will be given in order of "nearest" to "farthest". The first city will always be "Calgary" and
the last "Fredericton".</p>

<p>You will also be given a list of flights between pairs of cities, and the associated cost for each
flight, taxes included. There will never be a flight from a farther city to a nearer city -
Brett has already discarded those flights, deeming them to be a waste of time and money.
Bear in mind, however, that there may be more than one flight between any two cities, as
Brett is considering flights from all airlines.</p>

<p>Finally, you are presented with a number of queries. Each query is a single integer indicating
the maximum number of stopovers Brett will tolerate. For each query, your program must
calculate the least total cost of flights that would take Brett from Calgary to Fredericton
with no more than the requested number of stopovers.</p>

<h2>Input</h2>
<p>The first line of input contains a single number indicating the number of scenarios to 
process. A blank line precedes each scenario.</p>

<p>Each scenario begins with a number N (2 &le; N &le; 100), the number of cities, followed by N
lines containing the names of the cities. A city name is a string of up to 20 uppercase and lowercase
 letters. Next is a number M (0 &le; M &le; 1000), the number of flights available, followed
by M lines describing the flights. Each flight is described by its departure city, its 
destination city, and an integer representing its cost in dollars. The final line starts with 
Q (1 &le; Q &le; 10), the number of queries, followed by Q numbers indicating 
the maximum number of stopovers.</p>

<h2>Output</h2>
<p>For each scenario, your program should output the scenario number, followed by the least
total cost of the flights for each query. Follow the format of the sample output. If no flights
can satisfy a query, write "No satisfactory flights". Output a blank line between scenarios.</p>

<h2>Sample Input</h2>
<pre>
2

4
Calgary
Winnipeg
Ottawa
Fredericton
6
Calgary Winnipeg 125
Calgary Ottawa 300
Winnipeg Fredericton 325
Winnipeg Ottawa 100
Calgary Fredericton 875
Ottawa Fredericton 175
3 2 1 0

3
Calgary
Montreal
Fredericton
2
Calgary Montreal 300
Montreal Fredericton 325
1 0
</pre>

<h2>Output for the Sample Input</h2>
<pre>
Scenario #1
Total cost of flight(s) is $400
Total cost of flight(s) is $450
Total cost of flight(s) is $875

Scenario #2
No satisfactory flights
</pre>

<hr>
<i>Brett Shikaze</i><br>
<i>Calgary Collegiate Programming Contest 2006</i><br />
</body>
</html>
